A (ruined?) stone post and a part of a lintel, or part of a doorway, rise above Job's three friends on the right.
The rounded forms above the post, upper right, may be part of the structure but might be clouds.
Job sits on his mound-like bed of straw.

desc.objtitle: The Lord Answering Job out of the Whirlwind, Object 13 (Butlin 550.13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: God hovers, arms outstretched, in a whirlwind. Below are Job and his wife (left), both with hands raised in prayer. Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God's sublime energies; only Job and his wife gaze upward toward God. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, these are (from front to back) Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Green washes indicate grass in the foreground below the figures; the middle distance on the left margin has two columns and a lintel, perhaps a ruined part of a building. The outline of a distant mountain can be seen behind the columns.

component.illusobjdesc: God appears in a whirlwind. Clouds frame the whirlwind on the right and left.

God hovers in a whirlwind. He is ancient and gowned, with extremely long beard and spiky hair. He faces forward and to the left, arms outstretched horizontally. He looks slightly down towards Job and his wife. Both hands, with fingers slightly spread and palms down, are prominent. He may be blessing Job with his right hand and pointing to the right with the index finger of his left hand.

Job kneels on the left, covered only by the rough cloth covering his lap. He is old and bearded, and has long hair. He faces to the right and up, gazing upon the vision of God in a whirlwind. His arms are bent upward, with his hands clasped together in prayer. He appears to be surprised by the vision.

Job's wife kneels behind and to the right of her husband. Like him, her arms are bent upward with her hands together in prayer. Her body faces right, with her head turned partly forward and upward; she is probably looking at God above. She is gowned; her hair would appear to be long.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, the front-most figure is probably Eliphaz. He is kneeling with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. He is gowned and his hair would appear to be long. His arms are bent upward, cradling his head, and the fingers of his left hand are spread apart. His body faces to the left, with his head down.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, the middle figure is probably Bildad. He is probably kneeling, with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. He is gowned and his hair is short and curly (his identifying feature in several plates). His body faces to the left, with his head down; we see only his back and the top of his head.

Job's three friends bow down as though humbled and frightened by God in the whirlwind above them. Given our identifications of the three friends in Object 7, the third figure from the front is probably Zophar. Like his companions, he is probably kneeling, with his body bent forward in a severely contracted posture. His body must be facing to the left, with his head down, but we see only the top and left side of head.
Green washes indicate grass in the foreground below the figures.
The middle distance on the left contains some pillars and a long lintel, possibly part of a colonnade or building.
The outline of a distant mountain can be seen behind the columns.

desc.objtitle: When the Morning Stars Sang Together, Object 14 (Butlin 550.14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The complex design is divided by cloud bands into three sections. In the top section are stars and four youthful male angels. All are winged and partly nude, with indications of knee-length gowns or drapery; their arms overlap at 135 degree angles. Inscriptions in the engraved version of this design indicate that these figures are probably personifications of stars. The middle section is anchored by the ancient figure of God kneeling in the center of the design. His arms are outstretched horizontally. Beneath God's right arm is a youthful male riding (or possibly hovering above) one or more of the four horses beneath him. The halo or sun disc and the surrounding radiance suggest that he is a sun god, perhaps Apollo. Beneath God's left arm is a winged female holding the reins of two serpents. The crescent moon above her head identifies her as a moon goddess, probably Diana or Hecate. Job and his wife sit or kneel in the lowest section of the design. On the right are Job's three friends. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Green washes indicate grass in the foreground.

component.illusobjdesc: The four angels stand on a horizontal band of clouds that extends behind God's extended arms. The cloud extends in an arc above God's head in a way that suggests a halo.

A prominent cloud band separates God (center of the design) from the human figures of Job, his wife and three friends, seated below. The clouds descend toward the ground in the right and left margins to form an arch-like form.
Green washes indicate grass in the foreground.
There are 17 stars in the night(?) sky. Four of these stars are directly above the angel's heads, three are between each angel at knee-level, and the rest of the stars surround the angels.

In the top section are stars and four youthful and winged male angels. All are winged and have their arms raised and overlapping at a 135 degree angle. Their hands are raised, with palms turned upward. The fingers of all four angels are at least slightly spread. They face forward; the two angels on the left stride or walk with their right legs in front, and the two on the right with left legs in front. They all appear to be on their tiptoes. Their hair is somewhat long. The angels appear to have drapery from their waist to their knees, but are otherwise nude. Inscriptions in the engraved version of this design indicate that these figures are probably personifications of stars. Their open mouths indicate that they are singing.

God—ancient, gowned, and bearded with long flowing hair—anchors the center of the composition. He sits, squats, or kneels on a cloud band, with his right leg pulled up toward his body (as a result, his right knee and foot are prominent). He faces forward, with arms outstretched horizontally and palms down. The cloud band behind him creates a halo around his head. The flowing hem of his garment is prominent.

A youthful and nude male with arms raised horizontally, palms out, appears below God's right arm. He may be pushing against the clouds he touches with both hands. He faces to the left, with his torso bent forward. A halo, or perhaps the disc of the sun with beams of radiance, appears behind his head. He would seem to be hovering over, or possibly riding on, the backs of the four horses beneath him. A line extending above and to the right of his left shoulder suggests a wing. His hair is short and curly. Given all these attributes and emblematic associations, this is very probably a sun god, perhaps Apollo.
A youthful and nude male, perhaps Apollo, appears below God's right arm. A halo, or perhaps the disc of the sun with beams of radiance, appears behind his head.
Four horses, charging to the left in serried rank, appear beneath the youthful figure under God's right arm. Their manes appear to be flame-like.

A winged and gowned female appears below God's left arm. She faces forward and to the right, with her arms extended horizontally before her. The palms of her raised hands face down. Her hair may be fairly short and curly, though her right wing obscures the true length of her hair. She holds the reins of two serpents in her hands. The serpents below her and the crescent moon affixed to her head identify this figure as a moon goddess, perhaps Diana or Hecate (the latter more frequently associated with serpents).
The female figure below God's left arm holds the reins of two serpents in each of hand.

The female figure below God's left arm holds the reins of two serpents with scales and crests. They face to the right, with mouths open and protruding tongues. The foremost serpent's body loops once below the female figure.
There is a crescent moon affixed to the head of the female figure below God's left arm. This moon, as well as the darkness behind her, may indicate that it is night.

Job's wife sits or kneels lower left. She is gowned, with long hair, and faces forward and to the right with her head and eyes turned upward. Her arms are bent at the elbows and her hands are together in prayer. Her lips are slightly parted.

Job sits on the ground, the second figure from the left. His rough cloth extends over his lower body; his upper body is undraped. His left knee is drawn up toward his torso, with his left foot visible beneath the cloth. He faces forward, with eyes turned upward and head bent back. Both arms are crossed over his chest with his right wrist under his left palm; both palms are facing his chest. The rough texture of his flesh suggests the sore boils that afflict him. He is, as usual, old and bearded with long hair.

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Eliphaz is old and bearded with long hair. He wears a gown, and would appear to be kneeling. He faces up and to the left, with his eyes raised and his head bent back. His left arm is bent at the elbow, with his left hand raised, palm out, as if in prayer or supplication. The fingers of his left hand are slightly spread. His right knee is drawn up to his chest, making his right foot prominent.

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. Bildad (the center figure) has curly hair and a curly beard. He appears to be half- kneeling, with his left leg raised and bent at the knee, the bare left foot prominent. He is gowned and faces forward, to the left, and up, with his head bent back and eyes raised. His arms are not pictured (see the right arm and hand position of Eliphaz, the front-most figure).

Job's three friends sit or kneel lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The last, the friend furthest to the left, is partly obscured by Bildad; consequently, it is unclear whether Zophar is sitting or kneeling. He is gowned and bearded. He faces forward, to the left, and up, with head bent back and eyes raised.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God appears at the top of the design. He reaches down with his left arm, much like the figure on the frontpiece to *Europe* and points toward the circle or sphere in which are pictured Behemoth and Leviathan. God appears to lean on a cloud band that fills the night sky. Winged and gowned angels in attitudes of prayer frame the upper left and right portion of the design. The cloud band descends behind the angels and stops at the half-way point of the circle or sphere in the lower portion of the design. Job, his wife, and three friends kneel on the ground between God and the beastly sphere and look down toward it. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. The creatures within the circle or sphere are accompanied by reeds (some with catkins) and a frothy wave of the sea in which Leviathan disports.

component.illusobjdesc: God—old, bearded, and with long hair—anchors the top portion. He faces forward, but we see only his shoulders, arms, and head. His body is obscured by the cloud band on which he leans with his bent right arm and the upper part of his left arm. The fingers of his right hand (which may be holding the cloud) are spread apart. He reaches downward with his left arm, in a gesture very similar to the figure's on the frontispiece to *Europe*, and points downward with his extended left index finger. No clothes are clearly indicated, although one of the lines on his right wrist may be a sleeve rather than hair extending from his beard. His eyes are turned sharply downward or possibly closed. The jagged suffusion of light around God's head suggests a halo.
God leans on a band of clouds which descends in an arc behind the attending angels and extends downward on each side of the circle or sphere to its mid-point.
Bare earth(?) below Job, his wife, and friends, separates them from the sphere in the lower portion of the design and extends on both sides and below the sphere.

Two hovering angels, winged and gowned, frame God in the upper portion of the design. The angel on the left has short curly hair and faces to the right, with his arm bent at the elbow. His hands are together in prayer; his fingertips touch his chin. His lower right leg and foot are visible among the drapery trailing from his gown.

Two hovering angels, winged and gowned, frame God in the upper portion of the design. The angel on the right has long, curly hair and faces to the left, with his left arm bent at the elbow and the lower arm raised in an attitude of worshipful prayer. Although his hands are not visible, they appear to be behind the right side of his face. His lower left leg and foot are visible among the drapery trailing from his gown.

Job's wife sits or kneels in a contracted posture just to the left of her husband. She is gowned and has long hair; her upper body leans forward and she faces to the right. Her arms are crossed over her chest. Her eyes are cast downward, probably to look at the beasts below.

Job—bearded, old, gowned, and with long hair—kneels or sits in a contracted posture just below the figure of God. He faces forward, down, and to the right, with his arms crossed over his chest. He is probably looking down at the beasts to which God points. The fingers on his left hand are spread apart in an unusual gesture, while the fingers of his right hand are spread apart.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking, with downcast eyes, at the beasts below. Eliphaz leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. His left arm is bent sharply at the elbow, with his upper left arm close to his chest. His hair and beard are long; he is gowned. His left knee is prominent.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking, with downcast eyes, at the beasts below. Bildad leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. We see only his bearded face and left knee. His hair is curly.

Job's three friends kneel or sit just right of God's downward-reaching arm. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, they are, from right to left, Eliphaz, Bildad, and Zophar. All three may be looking, with downcast eyes, at the beasts below. Zophar leans forward, facing down and to the left, in a decidedly contracted posture. We see only his bearded face and left knee.
The great beasts, Behemoth and Leviathan, are pictured within a circle, perhaps to be understood as a cross-section of a sphere or globe.

Behemoth is the upper-most of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or globe. He stands, or possibly strides, facing left, with his head turned partly forward. Behemoth's muscles and tendons are visible, as though the creature lacked skin. His large left ear is anthropomorphic; large teeth or tusks extend from his partly-open mouth. His vertebral column is clearly enunciated, along with his ribs and tail. Hair is discernible on his face and the end of his tail. His tongue is visible within his slightly-opened mouth.

Leviathan is the lower of the two biblical beasts pictured within a circle or globe. He is a giant sea-serpent with two sets of large fangs and (three?) additional rows of smaller fang-like teeth. Leviathan spews fire, or flame-like breath, from his open mouth. His crested head faces up, while his scaly, and intermittently spiky body loops to the left.
Reeds with catkins frame Behemoth on the right and left. Additional reeds are to the right of Leviathan's crested head. The blades below Behemoth's belly suggest more reeds in the background.
Behemoth stands on marshy or sandy ground, perhaps on the shore of the sea in which Leviathan writhes.
Leviathan writhes in the sea. A frothy wave breaks just below him.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God sits at the top in the center. He holds an open book on his lap; he raises his right hand, palm out, in a sign of blessing. Radiance and beams of light surround him, and cloud bands on the right and left encircle him. Two large angels hover nearby, right and left. Tongues of flame contain a vision of Satan falling headlong with bolts of lightning into the fires of hell below. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow-devils and as the fallen selves of Job (right) and his wife (left). On the ground lower left, Job and his wife sit or kneel, beholding the vision in the flame. The foreground beneath Job and his wife appears to be rocklike and barren. To the right of Job's wife is a hill, or perhaps, a stone. They are on the edge of a cliff that drops off sharply to the right of the figures, and from which issues the fires of hell. Job's three friends kneel, aghast at the vision, lower right. Given our identifications of the friends in Object 7, these are Zophar (left-most in the group, seen from behind), Bildad (head only, upper right), and Eliphaz (nearest the lower right corner of the design).

component.illusobjdesc: God sits at the top in the center. He holds an open book on his lap and raises his right hand, palm out, in a sign of blessing. He is old, with a long beard and hair, and wears a flowing gown. The fingers of both hands are slightly spread apart. He faces forward, but leans and looks to the left. Beams of light and radiance illuminate the area around God. His knees are prominent.
God holds an open book on his lap.

God sits, apparently enthroned, at the top of the image. The area around him is aglow with radiance and beams of light. Arches of cloud frame this upper composition and extend two-thirds of the way down.

A large, winged and gowned angel hovers in the left margin. His body faces to the right, with his head turned toward us. His hair is long and curly. His right arm is bent upward, with the fingers of his right hand slightly spread. The gesture suggests prayer even though the other hand is not visible. His bare right foot is visible among the drapery of his gown.

A large winged and gowned angel hovers in the right margin. His right leg is bent at the knee and his body faces away from the viewer. His head is turned to the left and slightly down. His hair is long, and his bare feet are visible among the drapery of his gown.
Large tongues of flame appear below God; within them is a vision of Satan and two other figures (possibly Job and his wife).

Bolts of lightning appear below and on the left and right sides of the large tongues of flame below God. Below these are three more flames (of hell?) that issue upward between cliffs—or possibly the sides of a cave extending down to hell.
The area between the falling figures and the lower flames appears to be filled with smoke.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The figure on the left has her(?) head down, with her arms bent at the elbows and her hands clutching her head. She is seen from behind; her hair is long. Her legs are bent sharply at the knees and pulled up behind her torso; both feet are prominent. She is probably gowned, although there is little in the way of clear evidence of clothing other than traces of what may be diaphanous drapery over her buttocks.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. Satan is seen from the front, with his arms bent behind his head. His mouth is open, perhaps in an expression of pain. His genital region is obscured, perhaps by scales. His left leg is extended; the left foot is prominent. His right leg is bent at the knee. His nude body is slightly twisted.

A vision of Satan appears as the central figure in the large tongue of flame below God. The two figures with him have been variously identified as his fellow devils and as the fallen forms of Job (right) and his wife (left). All three are falling upside down into the abyss. The figure on the right has his head down, with at least his right arm bent over his head. Both arms may be wrapped around his head. He is seen from behind; his hair is long. His legs are bent at the knees and pulled up toward his torso; both feet are prominent. A few lines suggest that his twisted body is gowned.
Job and his wife sit on a plot of ground that descends sharply, like the edge of a cliff, just right of the two figures. The outline of what may be a mountain, hill, or large stone rises behind them.
Job's three friends appear to be sitting on a plot of ground in the lower right corner. The ground falls off sharply on the left, like a cliff.

Job sits or kneels lower left. He is old and his hair and beard are both long. He faces forward and to the right, with his head turned upward to view the vision in the large, central flame. He is partly nude, with his rough cloth draped over his loins and legs. His arms are at his side, with his hands down, palms facing down and fingers spread. This gesture suggests surprise. His lips may be slightly parted.

Job's wife sits or kneels, lower left, just right of her husband. She is gowned, with long hair and her lips slightly parted. Her arms are crossed over her chest, with the fingers of both hands slightly spread. She faces forward, with her head bent back to view the vision in the large, central flame.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner. Given our identification of the friends in Object 7, they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). Zophar is gowned; his hair is long and his left foot is prominent. He may be kneeling. We see him from behind, with his body twisted to the right and his head twisted to the left. He appears to be looking up at the vision in the large, central flame. His mouth is slightly open; he appears to be amazed or frightened by the vision.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner. Given our identification of the friends in Object 7, they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). Eliphaz is bearded and gowned; his hair may be long. He sits or kneels, with his body facing to the right and his head twisted back to the left and up, to view the vision in the large, central flames. His right arm is bent over his chest, with his right hand reaching upward toward (or perhaps just touching) his face. The position of his left arm is unclear; it may be hidden beneath his flowing beard.

Job's three friends huddle, in twisted postures, in the lower right corner. Given our identification of the friends in Object 7, they are Zophar (left), Eliphaz (lower right), and Bildad (just above Eliphaz). We see only the head of Bildad; he is bearded and his hair is curly. His head is turned upward to view the vision in the large, central flame.

objnote.p: This water color was probably added to the series c. 1821–27. It may have been worked on by someone other than Blake, such as his wife Catherine or Thomas Butts.

illustration.illusobjdesc: God stands on the left, his arms raised to bless Job and his wife who kneel before him, their hands clasped in prayer. Behind them are Job's three friends; they cover their faces as though hiding from his might, indicated by the great burst of radiance forming a halo around his head and shooting out pointed beams of light. A cloud arches in from the left, as though it were a platform or vehicle for God. Foreground vegetation and background hills and mountains provide the environment on the right.

component.illusobjdesc: God—old, gowned, and magisterial—stands on the left. His hair and beard are exceptionally long. He faces to the right, with his arms raised horizontally and the fingers of his hands spread apart. He is blessing Job and his wife. His bare right foot is prominent. A great burst of radiance with pointed beams of light forms a halo around God's head and upper body and extends to the left and right margins.
A cloud curves in from the left margin and extends below God's foot, as though it were a platform or vehicle supporting him above the blue sky, visible in the lower left corner.
A great burst of radiance with pointed beams of light forms a halo around God's head and upper body and extends toward the left and right margins.

Job's wife sits or kneels just to the right of God. She is gowned and has long hair. She faces left, with her head turned a bit toward the viewer. Her arms are bent at the elbows, with her hands together in prayer. Her eyes are raised toward God.

Job sits or kneels under God's hands. He is old and bearded with long hair; his rough cloth is draped over his thighs, lap, and left hip. His arms are down, with his hands joined in an attitude of prayer. He faces to the left and forward. There is a faint suggestion of drapery on his back.

Job's three gowned friends kneel together before God. The figures cannot be individually identified in this design. The first figure kneels facing to the left, his body hunched over; his arms are bent upward, and his hands clutch his head, hiding his face. His hair may be long, and the strands of hair falling over his lap suggest that he is also bearded. His posture suggests fear.

Job's three gowned friends kneel before God. The figures cannot be individually identified in this design. The second figure from the front kneels facing to the left, his body hunched over; his arms are bent upward, and his hands clutch his head, hiding his face. His hair may be curly, and the strands of hair falling over his lap suggest that he may be bearded. His posture suggests fear.

Job's three gowned friends kneel before God. The figures cannot be individually identified in this design. The third figure from the front kneels facing to the left, his body hunched over; his arms are bent upward, and his hands clutch his head, hiding his face. His hair may be curly. His posture suggests fear.
The foreground on the right includes some indications of vegetation, most likely grass.
The landscape in the right half of the design may include some vegetation, perhaps distant trees.
The landscape background in the right half includes low hills and more distant mountains.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job stands, facing forward, before a stone altar, above which rises a heart-shaped flame. His cruciform posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice. Job's wife kneels on the left; his three friends kneel with heads bowed on the right. Radiance and beams of light fill the sky, with distant mountains in the landscape (left and right) and, on the left, trees with stone(?) pillars and a lintel atop three of the pillars.

component.illusobjdesc: Job stands facing forward before a stone altar, above which rises a heart-shaped flame. His cruciform posture, with arms extended a little above the horizontal, suggests a self-sacrifice Job is giving to his God and perhaps a type of spiritual ecstasy. He is gowned and bearded, with long hair. His left leg is slightly bent and extended backwards, with his left foot resting on its tiptoe on the step of the altar. Both feet are prominent beneath the hem of his garment. His head is tilted slightly upward, his eyes are raised, and his mouth is open.

Job's wife kneels in prayer just left of her husband. She is gowned and has long hair. She faces away and to the right, with her head down. Her arms are bent upward with her right hand near her face. Her left hand is not pictured, but her posture and gestures suggest that her hands are together in prayer. Her bare feet are prominent.

Job's three friends kneel lower right. Like Job's wife, they may be praying. Their postures are somewhat contracted as they bend forward. We see them from behind. Given our identifications of the friends in object 7, they are Bildad (the central figure) with Eliphaz and Zophar to the right and left of Bildad. The representations of Eliphaz and Zophar are in this design insufficient to discriminate between them. Bildad's hair is curly.

Job's three friends kneel lower right. Like Job's wife, they may be praying. Their postures are somewhat contracted as they bend forward. We see them from behind. The soles of the feet of the figure on the left are clearly visible. Given our identifications of the friends in object 7, they are Bildad (the central figure) with Eliphaz and Zophar to the right and left of Bildad. The representations of Eliphaz and Zophar are in this design insufficient to discriminate between them. These two figures have long hair.
A large stone altar stands behind Job.
A large, triangular or heart-shaped flame rises from the altar behind Job. This is probably a burning sacrifice Job is offering to his God.
Green washes indicate grass on the ground below the figures. The ground rises into hills on the left, in the middle distance behind Job's wife.
Mountains rise in the background left and right of the altar.
Radiance brightens the sky behind the altar; beams of light descend from above.
Stone(?) columns appear in the middle distance on the left. Three are topped with a lintel; the two furthest right appear to be broken.

desc.objtitle: Every Man Also Gave Him a Piece of Money, Object 19 (Butlin 550.19)
desc.related: This pencil drawing, preparatory for the engravings, is a variant design for the same subject as Object 19 in the Butts series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job and his wife sit on the right. His left arm crosses his chest as he holds his upper right arm with his left hand. His left hand is on his knee. His wife crosses her arms over her breasts. Green washes indicate grass on the ground below and between the figures. A fig tree, bearing fruit, rises right of Job; behind Job and his wife are broken stones, perhaps columns or part of a wall. Three standing figures on the left are bringing charitable gifts to the now-humbled couple. These figures are, from left to right, a young woman holding a net-like purse containing gold(?) coins; a tall, bearded man holding a covered vessel of some sort; and a woman with her hair tied up, who holds a circular-and-diamond shaped object, perhaps jewelry, in her extended left hand. Grain stems with tassels and a distant mountain rise between the two groups of figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits on the right, his head humbly bowed. He is bearded and gowned. His hair is long. His left arm is bent at the elbow and extended across his chest, with his left hand resting on, or perhaps holding, his upper right arm. His right arm is extended along his leg, with his right hand resting on his knee. He faces to the left.

Job's wife sits just to the left of her husband. Her head is humbly bowed, with her eyes lowered and at least partly closed. She is gowned, with long hair, and faces to the left and down. Her arms are crossed over her breast.

The left-most youthful female standing in the group of three figures approaching Job and his wife has curly hair that appears to be tied up in a bun with a band across her head. She is gowned and faces to the right. Her right arm is bent over her chest. She holds a net purse containing gold(?) coins in the spread fingers of her lowered left hand.

The left-most female standing in the group of three figures holds a net purse containing gold(?) coins in her left hand with her index finger curled. The opening of the purse may be held in her right hand. Some of the coins fall below her left hand and into the bottom of the purse.

The man standing second from the right (in the group of three figures approaching Job and his wife) holds a lidded vase or container of some sort with both hands. His right arm is bent at the elbow. He has a beard; short, curly hair; a gown; and sandals on his prominent feet. He faces forward and to the right, with his right leg drawn a little behind his left. He is probably walking to the right. His posture suggests that he is about to give something from the container to Job and his wife.

The man in the group of three figures approaching Job and his wife holds a triangular object. This object has sometimes been described as a purse, but it clearly has a small finial at its top. This motif suggests that it is a covered jar, vase, or bowl rather than a purse. The container is decorated with a winged and gowned standing angel. One leg, probably the left, strides forward. The figure's arms are raised horizontally, with some object, possibly a descending liquid, below each hand. This figure may be a personification of a healing balm within the container.

The right-most figure (in the group of three standing figures approaching Job and his wife) is a young woman who holds, in her extended left hand (palm out), a circular-and-diamond shaped object, perhaps jewelry. She is probably about to give this to Job's wife. She has long hair that is tied up into a bun, and faces forward and right. Her shod left foot extending from the hem of her gown suggests that she may be walking.

The right-most figure (in the group of three standing figures approaching Job and his wife) is a young woman who holds, in her extended left hand, a circular-and-diamond shaped object. This is probably a piece of jewelry, perhaps a pendant of some sort or possibly a large earring.

Job and his wife may be sitting on a grassy mound, one that extends just right of Job's left hip. However, just above and to the left of his wife's right knee is an object with steps, possibly made of stone, that suggests a seat or bench.
A large fig tree grows right of Job and spreads is leafy and fruit-bearing limbs along the top margin.
Green washes indicate grass on the ground below and between the figures. The color also extends over the bank(?) right of Job's lower body.
Grain stems with tassels stand between the two groups of figures.
A distant mountain appears below the extended left arm of the rightmost woman in the group of three figures on the left.
A ruined wall (or perhaps a broken pillar on the left with a wall extending from it on the right) backs Job and his wife.

objnote.p: This water color was probably added to the series c. 1821–27. It may have been worked on by someone other than Blake, such as his wife Catherine or Thomas Butts, and was left unfinished.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Job the aged, bearded, and long-haired patriarch sits with three daughters (two at his side, one kneeling before him). His arms are raised at 135 degrees to point out the scene above him. The whirlwind of scenes above his head appears to be representative of Job's own life. Like Blake, Job is telling his story visually. The group of pictures shows, from left to right, a hovering (satanic) figure; farther to the right God appears, surrounded by angels as he looks downwards; there is another satanic figure on the far right, possibly with figures below. These scenes are circumscribed within clouds above a flock of grazing sheep. Hills, probably covered with vegetation, rise in the distance between the flock and clouds. In the grassy foreground, a dog is curled up sleeping on the left, and a lamb(?) is lying down in the far-right corner of the foreground.

component.illusobjdesc: Job sits in the middle of the design, his arms raised at 135 degrees. His extended hands, palms up and slightly out, blend into the scenes above, while he looks upwards. His legs are spread apart, with his bare left foot partly exposed beneath the flowing hem of his garment. His left knee is also prominent. His mouth may be slightly open(?) speaking to his daughters.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the left of her father. She is gowned and sits contrapposto with her legs together and knees prominent as they face to the left. Her right arm is bent at a little more than 45 degrees. She appears to be holding a writing or drawing utensil in her right hand, while balancing a paper(?) tablet on the scroll-like arm of the fashionable couch on which she sits. There may be vague indications of a drawing on the tablet. Her left arm is bent, and extends along Job's right upper thigh. Her left hand fades into Job's gown. She faces forward, with her head turned a bit to the right. Her hair is long and a little curly.

One of Job's daughter's sits just to the left of her father, and appears to be holding a writing utensil in her right hand, while balancing a large paper(?) tablet under her right arm and against the scroll-like arm of the couch on which she sits. There are faint suggestions of a drawing on the tablet.
One of Job's daughter's sits just to the left of her father. A book and scroll lean against her lower right leg.

One of Job's daughters sits just to the right of her father. She is gowned, with her right leg bent slightly backwards. Her left arm leans upon her father's left upper thigh, while her left forearm dangles perpendicular to his leg. She holds a feathered quill pen in her right hand. Her lowered left arm extends along her left thigh; she holds a scroll in her left hand. She faces forward, with her head turned to the left. Her hair is long and a little curly.
One of Job's daughters sits just to the right of her father. She holds a feathered quill pen in her right hand and a scroll in her left hand alongside her lower left leg.

One of Job's daughters kneels in front of her father. She faces to the left, with her upper body twisted away from the viewer so that we see her back. Her hair is long and curly; there is a crown of flowers in her hair. Her arms are bent upwards, and her hands are holding an opened book. The flowing hem of her garment is prominent.
One of Job's daughters kneels in front of her father. In her raised hands, she is holding an open book with faint lines that may indicate text.
One of Job's daughters kneels in front of her father. She wears a crown(?) of yellow and red flowers on her head.
A bat-winged satanic figure hovers in the scene within the clouds on the left. His arms are probably raised horizontally. A bolt of lightning may be descending from his right hand.

God, with long beard and hair and arms raised horizontally, hovers, facing forward, in a whirlwind pictured in the clouds above Job's head. God's raised hands have their palms down; his head is turned to the right. There are vague indications of figures in the cloud below God; he may be looking down upon them. The scene is basically the same as the one pictured in Object 13.
God appears in a whirlwind in the cloud above the central figure of Job.
A bat-winged satanic figure hovers in the scene within the clouds on the right. His body faces forward and to the right. There are faint indications of figures below the hovering figure.
Job and two of his daughters sit on a fashionable couch. Its scroll-like arms can be seen to the left of the daughter on the left and to the right of the daughter on the right.
Sheep graze right and left of the central figures.
Hills rise in the distance right and left of the central group of figures. Their coloring suggests that they are covered with vegetation, possibly trees.
Green washes indicate grass in the foreground. A few wavy lines suggest small plants.
A furry dog lies, curled up and apparently sleeping, lower left.
In the lower right corner, a lamb lies on the grass with its legs tucked underneath its body.
A vast cloud or clouds in the sky above the figures encircle three scenes from Job's life.

desc.objtitle: Job and His Family Restored to Prosperity, Object 21 (Butlin 550.21)

objnote.p: The text, quoted from Revelation 15:3, appears on the disc of the sun in the upper right portion of the design.

desc.related: This sketch, preparatory for the engravings, may be related, albeit distantly, to the foliage on the large central tree in Objects 1 and 21 in the Butts series of water colors.

These sketches, preparatory for the engravings, may be related to the dog with its head resting on the ground in the center foreground in Object 21 in the Butts series of water colors or to the dog with its head resting on a sheep in the center foreground of Object 1 in the Butts series of water colors.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The final design mirrors the first (Object 1), but with significant differences. Job's family, restored and reunited, stand and sing or play musical instruments. From left to right they are a youthful male playing double pipes; two of his brothers playing horns; another young son playing a curled horn; a youthful daughter holding a scroll and possibly singing; Job's wife, playing a mandolin; a young daughter holding a scroll (possibly another musical score) and perhaps singing; Job, playing a large triangular harp; a young female playing a lyre; a son playing a curled horn and another playing a large harp; and a final youthful male holding a pipe, his mouth open perhaps in song. The instruments hung in the tree in the first scene of the drama are now used to praise God. The great (oak?) tree from the opening scene again anchors the middle of the design; a sun appears over a distant mountain range on the right, and a crescent moon and one star (or planet) appear in the sky on the left. Seven sheep, including one ram, and a dog lie on grass in the foreground. A flock of sheep appear behind the legs of the figures.

component.illusobjdesc: Job's family, restored and reunited, stand and sing or play musical instruments. The patriarch stands, playing a large triangular harp, on the right side of the central tree. He is gowned and bearded; his hair is long and his lips are slightly parted. He may be singing. He faces forward with his eyes looking upward, his left arm raised at 135 degrees, and his left hand possibly pointing to the heavens. His right arm is bent across his body, with the fingers of his right hand (slightly spread) placed on the strings of the harp. His bare right foot extends beyond the hem of his gown.

The figure furthest to the left is a young male, one of Job's sons. He is gowned and standing, facing forward and to the right, with his left leg drawn slightly behind his right. His hair is curly and short. His arms are bent at the elbow and he holds two pipes on which he plays with spread fingers.

The second figure from the left is a youthful male, one of Job's sons, playing a horn. The little of his hair that is visible suggests that it is curly. He is gowned and standing, with his left arm raised at 135 degrees to hold his horn in his left hand. His head is bent back slightly, with his body facing to the right and his head facing a little up. His bare right foot is prominent.

The third figure from the left is a youthful male wearing a short gown or perhaps tights. This young man, one of Job's sons, plays a horn. He is standing, with his left leg slightly bent and his left foot behind his right and poised on tiptoe. His head is bent back slightly, with his body facing forward and to the right and his head facing up. His left arm is raised at 135 degrees to hold the large horn.

The fourth figure from the left is a youthful male, one of Job's sons, playing a horn with loops that suggest a spiral. He wears tights, or perhaps a short gown. He is standing, with his right leg slightly bent and his right foot behind his left and poised on tiptoe. He faces forward and to the right, with his head and eyes inclined downward. His right arm is bent upward to hold his horn.

The fifth figure from the left is a young female, one of Job's daughters. She is gowned, with her hair long and perhaps drawn up into a bun. She is standing, facing forward and to the left. Her arms are at her sides and she holds a scroll or manuscript, perhaps of music in her hands. Her lips are slightly parted, indicating that she may be singing. Her left foot extends from under the hem of her garment.

Job's wife stands on the left side of the central tree, the sixth figure from the left. She faces forward, holding and playing (with fingers spread) a mandolin. She is gowned, with her left foot extending from under the hem of her garment. Her bent right hand is lowered onto the strings of the instrument. Her hair is long, and her head and eyes are inclined slightly upward and to the right.

A young female stands in front of the central tree and between Job and his wife. She faces forward with her head bent upward and slightly to the left and her eyes raised. She is one of Job's daughters. She is gowned and has long, curly hair. Both feet emerge just beyond the ruffled hem of her garment. Her slightly bent arms extend outward from her sides, and she holds in her hands a scroll or manuscript, perhaps of music. The fingers of her right hand are spread. Although her mouth is not open, she may be singing.

The figure furthest to the right in the family group is a young male, one of Job's sons, with long hair. He wears tights and stands with his right knee slightly bent and his right foot drawn back and on tiptoe. He faces to the left, with head bent back and eyes raised, and holds a pipe in both hands. His mouth is slightly open; he may be playing the pipe (although not at this moment) or singing. His left arm is bent upward at his side to hold the pipe.

The second figure from the right is a young male, one of Job's sons, who stands facing forward and to the left. He holds, and plays upon, a large harp. He wears tights and has his right leg drawn behind his left. His right arm is bent upward to play the harp with fingers spread. His hair is short and curly. His lips are slightly parted; he may be singing.

The figure third from the right is a young male, one of Job's sons, who faces forward with his head bent back and eyes raised. He wears tights; his left leg is slightly bent and drawn behind his right, with his left foot on tiptoe. He holds and plays a curled horn with one loop in it. His right arm is bent upward to hold the horn. His hair is short.

The figure fourth from the right (and standing just right of Job) is a young female, one of Job's daughters, facing forward and to the right. She is gowned and has long hair. She holds a lyre in her left hand and plays upon its strings with the spread fingers of her right hand. Her mouth is slightly open; she may be singing. Her right arm is bent horizontally across her body.

A large flock of sheep can be seen behind the standing figures, right and left. Some of the creatures are standing and grazing; at least one is lying on the ground. Given that this large flock is so closely associated with the human figures, perhaps we are to think of the youthful males (and females?) as shepherds.
Green washes indicate grass on the ground below the figures and below the sheep.
A group of animals (all but one a sheep) lie in the foreground. The one exception is a dog, facing left in the center of the group. The sheep furthest to the right is a ram with looped horns.
A large tree—probably an oak—with a heavy trunk stands in the center of the design. Its leaves spread out along the top margin.
The top lip of a mountain range appears above the figures on the left. In the sky above is a crescent moon and a star or planet (possibly Venus, given the rising sun on the right).

The top lip of a mountain range appears above the figures on the right. The disc of the sun appears just above the mountains; its radiance and beams of light fill the sky above. The sun is inscribed with words quoted from Revelation 15:3; see the textual transcription. Given the joyous nature of the design, this surely must be a rising (rather than setting) sun.
Words quoted from Revelation 15:3 are inscribed within the disc of the sun, upper right; see the textual transcription.
